entry.title: How to Add Stuff on GitHub via Command Line
entry.content:
1. Register an “username” and login in GitHub

  2. Click “+” sign at the upper right corner to create a new repository and give it a name

  3. Open your repository and you can see the clone URL is located at the right side, for instance: https://github.com/yourname/yourRepositoryName.git

  4. Copy the URL of your repository and clone it from remote to local by typing: git clone https://github.com/yourname/yourRepositoryName.git

  5. See the current configured remote repository for your fork by typing: git remote -v

  6. Add something to the local respository, sush as a “README.md” file

  7. Push the new added file “README.md” to the remote version on GitHub by typing:

  8. git init

  9. git add README.md

  10. git commit -m “your commit remark”

  11. git remote rm origin

  12. git remote add origin https://github.com/yourname/yourRepositoryName.git

  13. git push -u origin master

  14. Typing your username and password to submit the changes to your repository on GitHub

  15. Mission Complete. Now you can refresh the web page of your repository to see the “README.md” file that justed added

Bonus:

For removing the file/document named “sometingToRemove” of your local respository:

  • git rm sometingToRemove

entry.title: First Blog
entry.content:
After several hours efforts, I have my Octopress blog in the end.

Hello, World !

Then, what to write ?

I intend to:

  • Share technology about Programming and Software Development

  • Share Experiences, Lessons and Thoughts

  • Record Life and Time

  • Write about Other interesting stuff
